element_texts.text: Completed

Bangor July 21st 1839
Dearest Mother       also brother
Charles was down here Friday and gave me a letter from you, but I hardly had a chance to speak? to him.  I saw him coming in, in the morning, as I was out hoeing praties. but before I had eaten my breakfast, and got down town, he was gone; So I dont know whether he got some money of Morren?, or sold his wool, or got me a ? on Me!  I have been tryingunderlined to prepare a composition, also writing to Ann about some book etc. to day; rather worldly employment to be sure, but I am hurried, there is great scrabble, in school now about review and preparation for examinations?  There is one thing which I want a little advice about.  I expect that James ? Walker would be very glad of an invite to go up to Milo? with me and make hay a spell.  Now the thing is would it do?  considering etc.  He would have the tactunderlined to see whether he wanted I spose, but I think he would like to come if he were urged a little.  I should not have written now except for this, as I wrote so lately  Somehow I thought Charles did not look quite so well, healthy, as usual, when he was down here.  Is his health good now? I did not have a chance to see or speak to him, hardly at all, I don't know whether he noticed me in morning, or not, I was up to the farm with Mr. W. and James, hoeing potatoes; but he took the Centre St. so I could not speak to him.  I have not hardly concluded yet, whether to run home and to to haying before school is finished or stay and take the consequences at the Examination. I have been trying to hammer out a composition for a about a week.  As I had nothing to write about and nothing to write about I could not make out much.  I have been trying to ? patch up something, by taking a peice out one book and a slice out of another, a line here and a sentence there, twisting it every way, but I fear they will convict me of Plagiarism  I could not do any better no harm though as I can see
Completed

Bangor September 3rd 1899

Dear Mother
I am here again at my old stand, although not yet hardly settld in business I suppose that Joseph has got home by this time, and can inform you of all our doings.  I thought it would be best to have the wool here and I might be able to sell it sometime; it is now safely stored away up garret.  Hardy any one wanted to buy wool, it had fallen at Boston and New York, and they said they have lost money by what they had bought, 33 and a third seemed the common price, but at Campbell and Mils, I was offered 37 half.  I thought Charles would not be willing to have it sold at that price and that it had better stay here.
On going to school this morning, the scholars all appeared glad to see me again, more afraid they had lost me so, but Mr. Worcester said never a word till the Latin Class were called, he heard all before me, and then addressed me thus; "Isaac, you left school before the close of the term, and according to the regulations of the Committee, I have no authority to admit to the school, without a certificate from Mr. Abbot, C.L.L.B."
At recess I left the school and went over to Mr. Abbots office.  After inquiring into the particulars of the case, he very readily gave me a certificate of readmission.

I suppose I could send anything to Boston next week by James.  He will probably go next week Wed.  Possibly not till the next bout a week.  If you could send me a letter here I could send it by him-easily.
Completed

Mr. Asa Walker is now gone to Wilton, with his ((unclear)) started yesterday morning, will be back Friday or Saturday, Mrs. Walker is I should think in much better health than when I left here, and does the work while Mr. W and his sister are gone.  James is going to ((unclear)), after  'Lection, he says Mr. Walker has got two new young pigs which he intends to keep through the winter.    The other pigs are great hogs.  I find that I am rather behind the rest in some things, they have a week start of me.  There is a class beginning Comstocks Philosophy, and I must begin with them although I lack time for it.  There are 11 new scholars this term besides of who left at the beginning of summer, returned.
There is a class, many of the older boys and those who have studied algebra going to go through the new Leonards Arithmetick, lately published, to refresh their memories etc.
It is very oppressively warm to lay, especially in a schoolhouse;  James says I shall soon lose the flesh I have gained, studying, this weather.  It comes very hard to wear a thick warm coat all day, or a stick either.
I left behind as you will perceive my umbrella, shoes, inkbottle, they can be sent with the pantaloons.  I don't know but it would be best if I had that white jacket.  I rather think that that old wooden frock coat, which I wore some, when I first went home, (hanging upstairs) might be fixed by merely cutting off a few inches, of the bottom, putting on buttons etc, so that I could wear it to school considerable this fall.  At least digging potatoes etc.
It would save my other, (of which there is need/, and also, my ((unclear)) much more than a short jacket.
Completed

Wed. 4th
School does not keep this afternoon.  I wish it had a Scientific Class Book; there is a class commencing it, it is just what I very much need to study, I should think.  I have a great notion of giving Algebra and paying more attention to History, Philosophy -.  I cannot attend to all Latin, Greek and every-thing at a  time.
James told me I had better get my coat mad by Mr. Fox ((unclear)) Market Sq,:that he did his work rather cheaper than other and he thought full as well; he always doe stheir work.  He says he don't know of any noman, who makes coats here, soforth.  I have been into Mr. Fox's shop; his fixes one; for cutting and making a coat $5.00.  Trimmings, also extra $2,25 for frocks $2,00 for dress coats, cutting, alone, 75.  He said it would take 2 quarter yds for me a frock.  1 eighth for a dress coat.  There is but 2 yd of that of mine is there?  I am sure I don't know whether it is to be a frock coat, or not!  AT some of the other shops, at least the price for making $6, $5.020 is a s far as my cash extends, and I ought to have some boots immediately.
I want to know what it is best to do about the coat, selling the wool to, right away.  Mr. Fox could not make the coat until next week if it was there now, he ways.
There is to be a select school for young Ladies established here in a month or two, which I guess would have been a good situation for Anne, but the Teacher is already engaged, I believe at Mifs.  From Brunswick.  IT is expected that an assistant for Mr. Turner in the H.S will be wanted in the spring I believe.
Completed

Bangor September 15th 1839

Dear Mother
I received a bundle for you Thursday the 12th inst. containing a coat, pantaloons, vest and stockings;  I wanted those old shoes that I forgot also as I have nothing to wear now anywhere but the great thick boots.  The pants I shall wear a good deal, I guess, this fall, they are fixed up nicely.  The coat also will do me some good.  I guess but the sleeves and collar are so large that it looks awkwardly here; It would be just the thing to mean about all my work this fall and to school in cold, rainy weather, if I had any kind of a jacket; a thin one a baise ones are much worn here to work on school or anything a chick one.  I don't know but that camblet or old white one, only Joseph wants it and it is too very thick;  Something that would do to wear under it.  One frock coat wider another would not do so well you know.  You see how one want satisfied only makes another?  I believe that the price of wool is rising.  I guess that it will sell soon pretty well.  I had better sell it if you get, 50 per ((unclear)) had not I.  The tailor says that I can have a frock from my coth by  having a velvet collar, which would cost $1,25 and they are much worn so, on it would make a dress coat and a single breasted vest.  I concluded that the dress coat, vest, and $1,25 would do me more good than the frock coat.  ((unclear)) frocks?? are much the most worn , now here, he says that there will have to be some more silk and some ((unclear)) for binding.  Moreover that he would wait a piece for a part to pay, if it was not on hand to.  I guess that he's a real good sort of man.  Elen. T Fox Well Square.  he is to get the rest of silk etc.
Completed

I have left of studying Algebra as I found I could not get along with it fervently.  I find that the others have got the start of me somewhat since the 26th of July last.  Some of them studied some during the vacation I guess.  We shall commence the Greek Reader tomorrow.  Mine has not yet arrived but I guess borrow one from somebody.  I do not study History as yet but think I shall when the class gets to English History, as I feel a great lacking in that reflect.
I guess that the Scientific class Book that they have here is not the one Amos is acquainted with, this is an advanced work, goes entirely further than Cornstocks, it takes Natural Philosophy in it  widest sense - Mon 16th I found at the steamboat office this morn a bundle for me, containing two school books for me, a signing sentences for Ann, and 3 letters, 2 of them from Mr. Bush.  I will send Josephs and Mothers' as soon as I can with this etc.  The freight was $5,25.  The book are just the thing, I wanted.  I want to know what Ann gave for them.  The other scholars have to give $1,12half for the reader here!  I expect we shall have to fly round to keep along when we study in the Reader too.  They say it is awful hard.
5'O'clock Coming home from school tonight, I perceived Mr. Ellis, wandering about in search of the habitation of me F. Addams. 1 Kenneth place and directed him to it, and I meant to get him carry up my bundle of letters etc.
I am losing my required flesh and strength fast already (line unclear due to crease))
I certainly can't enjoy myself as well as at work.  I shall study till next spring if health permits and then you see.  You must all write.  Ann must write to me, and all of you.  I feel almost like an exile!!  Don't think I am discouraged on however or dissatisfied with my situation for it is not so intolerant - but
Completed

Bangor Cot 2d 1839  Sunday noon

Dear Mother
I got here as Eliab has told you when you read this.  I am here at Ms. Walkers:  Eliab I feel has a cold side home.  He ought to have had some mittens.  Send me my gown and my shirt that Isaac had at Barn for with the potatoes if possible.  I did go to meeting this forenoon but am going this afternoon.  They say that probably (on account of headwind etc.) the steamboat will not arrive here tonight & therefore I will not repost till about noon tomorrow.  I have eat dinner here, Mr Walker's folks have got 1 new wrinkle - they take a great long baked potato in 1 hand & a knife in other & dunk it into a bowl of milk & eat it with a spoon like bread & milk.
Good bye, Joseph with a poor pen.
1 o'clock, The steamer has not yet arrived.  It may come up in the night as there is a good moon.  If it arrives in the morning it will start to depart at a new moon.  The usual time of the books arrives is 9 o' clock.  R.M of starting out M. - but it is very irregular now a days - sometimes when foggy I has not started until 8 in the morning.  I am at the present time up in Isaac chamber which is very respectable & warmed by a drum in the stove funnel!! with Isaac's steel pen in my hand, Isaac sitting by my side reading & James S Walker putting on his coat to go to a evening meeting.  These drab trousers are rather cold and thin, I fear it will be cool on board the boat with a deck passage.  I attended the Pomroy meeting cet apres dinee Text "The path of the just is a shining light that shineth more & more unto the perfect day." Proverbs 4:8
Monday, half past 9 at M The Bangor has not arrived yet but is expected every moment.  The Bangor banks have all stopped spare payments & the bills of the Bangor Bank or considered doubtful good - I have exchanged the $85.00 Bangor bank bill ((from Col. see)) for two of the Frankfort bank current about here but uncurrent in Boston - Bank of Newburyport of Portland a $2 - & a $1- good in Boston or anywhere.  (I changed it at E.J Dowers)

How is my jacket to be sent and render me by afternoon?  Can you cut it without me to fit it by?
Completed

I can let Isaac have the $2.00 of the Frankfurt bank bills & perhaps more but the others $7.00 is current in Boston.  Perhaps it is for the best that the steamer does not arrive as the sea will have some time to calk after the gale of Sat & Sunday, before I start.  Isaac is in school -  half past 10 A.M.  Not come has the steamer P.M  The steamboat has not arrived yet.  I have been "looking" all day & I am most sick if not ((unclear)) of the Andre.  I sincerely with I had worn the dark coloured pants as these are thin & have no lining.  I wish I was at home.  I have given Isaac $2.62 of the $10.50 which I seen.  He has paid Mr ((unclear)) the $1.00 due for making the coat, I carried his coat down  let "  " to have it enlarged about -the waist.  All or about day keep this more I was on the steamboat wharf - calculate to be tomorrow morning.  I looked at the book store this afternoon  and read Feilty Hazell one of the Temperance Tales. Tuesday morn 6A.M The steamboat has not come what is to be done.   
12 A.M the steamer arrived about half hour ago.  ((unclear)) about half hour.  I attended the Launching of a schooner this forenoon.
Good bye, from your affectionate son Joseph.  Good bye all.
Tuesday eve
The boat steam boat, (Joseph and all) started a little after one o clock today, it did not arrive till about 11 or aver on account of the violent North on N.E wind.  Sunday Monday etc the Portland did not stand from Boston till - Joseph has staid here at Mr. Walkers, took 6-7 meals here.
I don't know but it was rather bad for him to stay here so long but it could not be helped, and Mr. W. told him to stay make himself perfectly easy.
Joseph got rather tired of waiting for the boat:- doing nothing or loafing as the term here is:  he helped me cut wood some.  head home etc.etc.
Joseph carries up a letter to put in the Boston P.O from I.L Walker and just before the boat started, A Mr. Little of this city with whom James is some acquainted was enquiring for some one to send a letter.
Completed

Wednes. afternoon

Dear Mother
I got here in good time about three o clock found Mrs. W without any girl, a new one came Monday Morn; ; James W. is coming here in a week or two, to help tear down the house, and a carpenter is coming too, by and by!  The girl is quite young (note the good old one who cannot come yet) and without exactly asking I have found out that Mrs. W would not want any addition to the family but I think Lucy had better come and board at Mr. Cutlers, they would probably board here a little cheaper if she did her own washing and perhaps might pay part in produce at his store and C. take the money instead.  She would learn as much there about behavior company as here, and with regarding to introducing her time out of school, she must learn to have decision of character and independence enough to do what is right and proper without being led by others; a most useful lesson and one that can be gained best by experience.  I should have gone on up to Mr. Cutler's this afternoon if it had just raised, but there is not doubt but they will take her and she must get ready as soon as she can.  I shall send word as soon as I have been there and she had better come as soon as possible afterward, so as to be here as near the beginning of the term as she can.  Well, what kind of a school will she go to?  Why, the committee who came in yesterday, called it a new select school for girls, in telling the scholars (and teacher too I suppose) how much they expected of them.  It consists of 44 girls, from 10 to 15 mostly, no boys, so you see it is just the school for Lucy and if she comes with a determination to study she can improve much and be a help to me.  I should rather she would go to Mr. Pomroy' meeting and perhaps I can arrange it so as to have her in our S.S in that case she would attending meeting here in the forenoon, though that meeting is as good as this.

 I want my thick shoes to work in the garden with.
Completed

Bangor  Wed. 22nd 1840P.M

Dear Mother
You know how Ann all last term kept thinking as how she had a bad school to manage, and did not get along well; the committee were not satisfied, did not have a good examination and all that.  I said that she did nicely.  How did it turn out?  This term she has got, I suppose the very best school, taught by a female in the city!!  A New Select School!!! consisting of girls only; just about the right number; just about the right age; and moreover, just the very place for Lucy!!!!!  The next thing is, I suppose, for Lucy to get here as soon as possible.  It seems as if you would need her at home this Summer, but I think it is altogether too good a chance to be lost, or found every day either, especially if she can get boarded at Mrs Cutlers for 7/6 per week.  Can't you get little Olive again this Summer?  It is a pity that Charles cannot improve this nice early spring, so as to get his crops in good season, and for once in the May, get fairly beforehand.  He ought to have had some of his wheat sown before this rain today: but I suppose he has not.  I fear he will conclude that his 6 days time and fuss spent for 10, dollars worth of hayseed, that he wanted to sow himself, was mmmm, not quite wasted, - but this applied.  It is so dark that I can write no longer.
I have sold the smallest box of butter for 14 cts per pound, 12 quarter pound $1,71 I have enquired somewhat, but do not think I shall be able to sell the seeds.  It is too late, every body has got a full stock, more than they can sell; it is possible that I could sell them for money I would take pay out of the store, not ((unclear)).
I was pretty lucky in selling the butter at 14 even I think; they were selling good butter out of the stores at 12 and 13, but one morn Almer Taylor who appeased to be a connoisseur, bring a little for his own family, took it home to use, but did not want the large box. 2 pounds was enough.  Perhaps I can sell some of the seed, as may as he want to sow, off to Mr. Walker, he has got all his seeds & garden to buy.
Completed

There is a class beginning French this term, or going to, I wish I could study with them, but I don't hardly know whether I should have time.  Besides I guess that should have to buy new books some, they begin upon a translation, which Ann has not got, you see I wish Joseph could be here this term, I do wish I could be at home this summer if it was not for studying most, I would be much more pleasant.  It's much harder work to study than to labour!!! To me at least (specially in the Summer) I sometime think how much better it would be if I could be to work at home, out of school where it is really needful; than to be here fusty fustin on little but garden, wheeling hour after hour from one end to the other, bc Labour which might do more good somewhere else.
We are getting to work in our garden considerably, all ready to be done.  By the way if Charles is down again soon, I meant to send up some little lilac bushes if they would be taken care of, I could get some, lots of little (sehuleh???) flow roun garden stairs.  
I want a palm leaf hat, right away.  How shall I get it?
23
My cloth one is so warm; it does very well to wear to school this 2 months but ((unclear)) work when it is as warm as today, for instance, and a shock cap is rather ((unclear)  I don't to give 2/6 for one again.  What has become of my old one.  I have been to Mr Cutlers today after school, found Mr. Harth there visiting Naomi, I suppose, married says she will take Lucy cheaper than she would a stranger and for what we think right, I told her that I pay 150 including washing and that you would be glad to have her do her own if it would come cheaper.  Lucy must try to get her things in as good order as she can, so that what sewing she has to do will be plain and easy.
She will need to study considerable out of school because I shall need her help in school some I have 45 girls, many of them the best scholars selected from other schools and all the girls in Mr. Valentines: there will be much expected of me and justly.  Isaac rather implies, that I have the best school, because they consider me

  The butter is still in Parsons and Jaskery store unsold.  I miss in there Day 24th he said that butter be rising soon, and he could sell it that it for better.
Completed

so good a teacher but I know it not so, but because it happened to be convenient to make such an arrangement; I shall try to convince them that I am a good teaching this lesson, I certainly have a fair chance.  The sooner Lucy gets here the better her summer gowns will be suitable to put on soon, some wear pink dresses now.  She will need that she figured one of mine first.  Abby Hill one of my scholars.
I am waiting for you to write part of a letter before I write to A




Care of Mr Charles . W Rich
Milo


Ann & Isaac, 1840 Bangor
Completed

Bangor Feb. 3rd 1840

Dear Mother
Charles was down here Sat. Feb. 1, but I did not see him at all!  Which was altogether too bad.  You see Ellen Lee called the eve before and said he was coming - he was not here till after school time and it was Sat and school kept by reason of Compositions till about dinner time.  So after dinner, I went downtown to look for him, hunted all over town and found him not!  Came home, and he had been here, staid on a few minutes and started for Milo!  I suppose that I went one way to look for him and he came up to Mr. W.s another and so we escaped one another.  I was a good deal disappointed.  You can't hardly think how much good it does one, when away to see anything from home.  Just to see the horses would be a pleasure.  You did not make out to write a very long letter, I believe and Eliab did not write any at all, what is the reason?  
You said you was going to send Josephs' last letter, but it did not come.  Also "Josephs letter to me, that we sent out, ought to be sent back, honerer,"
Ann and I have recently written to Boston, a letter.  I received a letter from James Walker at Hancocks, a while ago and have lately answered it.  Sent last post Feb 1.
There is one thing, which I have forgotten every time, that  we have written home this term.  There was a little bundle of papers, tied or bound up with a paper, which I left at Milo, among the books be that Ann was to bring down.  She brought A not and I want it very much here.  It contained many different things, in south of things, skeletons of Comportions etc.!!
Completed

Besides that, there was a kind of a book that I made a good while ago a note of some translations of Geography on part of.  It will never be of any use to anyone there and I should use it here.  That was also left among the books, etc. that Ann, was to bring down.  If these things are, "lying round", as is most likely, I wish you would send them down when there is a chance, neither trouble or cost.  Also Mr. Walkers letter to me while I was at Milo. The pants you sent back mended me just about the thing -just right every way - I shall wear them a good deal.  My other pantaloons, on account of their being so much too long; (which makes them wrinkle up and look very ugly,) are not hardly decent to wear to meeting, however, I get along after a portion by keeping my Surtout on pretty constantly!!  If you make it up another pair, do make them 3 inches shorter, at least, they will last very much longer.  The drab ones 'you mended', are plenty long.  NOW.
Charles, ought to take better care of his 'finger'.  I expect that he hurt it once, trying to get my foolish little pony in the ferry port.  It may be because I am not singer myself, but, I really have no faith in singing schools.  I can not help thinking myself, that it would be very much better, for both Charles & Eliab to spend their evenings at home, staying or sending some good useful or entertained in instruction books.  Besides, the money they pay Mr. Thatch won't furnish them with oil all winter!!  I have no objection to Mr. Hatch's getting some money I almost said that he might it it by his; or another other way, but (blacksmithing, for all ma ( but that is too.
However, I don't think that he is anything extra in singing a Mr W heartily defines all his singing as musicle and he is ?
Completed

Feb 10th 1840

Dear Mother
I write the following about a week since, but hurry bc. has prevented my finishing the thing, - it can hardly be called a letter.  I expect I took this old sheet about as much from laziness as anything.  Too lazy to write a good letter, on a good sheet, with a good pen.  So I took this to scribble on.
Is it not queer neater this winter, the snow is most all gone here, I guess Charles will not make out much, this winter, the weather, - be, have been such.  Had had better have kept school.  Mr. Walker is going to look up housekeeping, for a time and by, but not right away, perhaps in March what I do then?  Hope to get another place, or go home?  I don't hardly know whether I had better stay here and go to school this summer, (even if I can) or go to work, on the farm, or something.  I believe I have not changed my mind up about NOT going to college.  If I should go, I never should make anything. (line drawn)
Eliab must learn just as much as his situations permits, this does he have the mood to saw?  He don't have many calls to take care of when Charles is not there with the Horses - I wish I had him in my study, here some of these good long evenings, I would make him learn.  I know he must study evenings, much better than to go to singing schools!!
I get along some in my studies in Latin, Greek, but not very fast.  I find I have filled my sheet, such as it is, after a fashion, but I don't see as I have written much of any thing.  Do, take time and write me a good long letter, I want to know how things get along etc.
I.S Metcalf
Completed
Completed

I have just been out to Mr Parker.  Says thanks a majorly and best part of the district now little to keep but even if meet up again  & so he  is to deter ((unclear)) He is anxious I should take it if possible instead of woodsman.  Board there.  Write more ((unclear)) if I don't.
Completed

Foxcroft Dec 7, 1843

Dear Mother
I can hardly realize now that you are two or three hundred miles from here, although I have been at home and staid a week.  Lonesome enough it seemed there, with no Mother and no Eliab.  The very idea of Home, seems to be made up principally of "Mother," and two or three others.
Our Examination at the Academy came off pretty well, rather better than usual, it is said.  We had a very good Exhibition the next day, or evening rather.  It was a long day and a damp & cloudy evening, but the meeting house was crowded full, and the audience sat with perfect patience and attention, till past one o clock, commencing at six.  Charles and Lucy did not come up, on account of the weather.  I was very sorry.  I wanted their opinion of the exact and comparative merit of my Oration!  
I spoke 20 min, house by accident very warm, & took cold through my carelessness, but have about got over it.  After settling up the Exhibition matters, I went home and stayed most a week.
Mr Fox died, as you have probably heard, ere this, on Wed. morn Nov. 22nd.  I did not hear it till I got home Sat night.  Charles watched with him the night he died.  I had a real lazy time, and got rested.  Lucy was pretty well.  Charles, I thought looked as if he wanted to see his Mum.  Perhaps as much as I did!!
I have commenced my school, and find it a case I have had near 70 scholars already, shall have some more after Thanksgiving (today) (They are almost all small ones, and such a restless, uneasy, ((unclear)) set as I never saw before.  The control I
Completed

management of a hundred of the wildest or roughest young fellows, right out of the woods, or the street; in their teens, or olde would be nothing to it, as a kind of patience at least.
I shall probably have some larger scholars, next week.  I have 6 classes in reading, 5 in Arithmetic, 4 in Geography, 3 in Grammar, 1 in Philosophy, History, Algebra, 10 to 20 in a class generally.  I board at Mr Parkers'. I like the place pretty well, except that I do not have a room to myself which is rather disagreeable, as I have to keep to the hours of the other people instead of such as just me and go to bed in season!  10 o clock bed time here!!
I shall not have much chance to study this winter, I guess.
Dec 27th My letter will get out of date, into the new year before I send it.  Last Sat.  Mr Task & P got a horse & sleigh & went down to Milo in the P.M to see the folks & spend the Sabbath.  Most unfortunately, we found Lucy sick a bed, all piled up with a lame ankle, unable to move!  You may imagine the fix!  However, we brushed round.  Almeda really undertook, fixed up her room & entertained us hospitably!  PM the end things leaped off not so bad as they might be although Lucy felt dreadfully about it at first.
We went up to Brownville to meeting & finally came back Sabbath eve, as there was prospect of a storm in the morning.  I expect Lucy was a little too smart about her Thanksgiving washing bc, 'overdid' & took cold.  Dr, Kimball came & prescribed Calomel!!  However she was much better Sunday & I guess was only a Cold & Rheumatism, and she will get over it in few days.  Charles has not done much upon the house yet.  But Mr Gilman is coming to keep him soon.  Almer Butler has been threshing:  the grain turns out most miserably.
Completed

Joseph is getting along pretty well in his school I
believe. He is a good teacher, I know. He has an Indian
in his school. 40 or 50 scholars. Universalist people.
I hardly know how I am prospering. I hear some
complaints of my punishing, which I have found it im-
possible to do without entirely. People are very ready to blame a
teacher as not being strict enough, but no one is willing
to have their children punished. School averages 60 & up-
wards, all weathers. Writing school Sat. R. M.'s Flatter my-
self I am a pretty good "Writing Master," if this letter does belie it.
My school is very tiresome. I am so exhausted & lazy that I
do not make out to study much evenings. I sleep 8 to 10 hours too
instead of 4 to 6 as I did in the fall. Very bad habits!
Mr. Parker's folks had a "donation party", on Thurs. 21. 
About 100 people there P.M. & evening. Presents [?] of 40, or 50, [?].
I am anxious to hear from you. It is most two months.
I show willing to pay postage once a month, at least.
Eliab must write. I am [?] to hear where you are & what
you are doing. How does Eliab spend the winter? He must
not forget his religion. Young Christians have especial
need to watch.
Habits of idleness & inapplication of mind are easily formed, but
thrown off with difficulty.   The state of religion is low here & 
seemingly everywhere about.   I hope you will write me
some good, loving, oldfashioned letters, as you used to; have
Eliab write, do him good. Ann too.  I wish you all a "happy
new year"!" This wish includes all friend & relatives, everybody I can remember, at least

      Your Affectionate and ever mindful son
                                                         Isaac S. Metcalf
Completed

I really wish you or someone else, would tell me what to do in the world.  I have, providence, willing , a life to spend & a living to  get, somehow, but I truly know nothing how or where. Pray who does,  It is certainly time I did.  It can hardly be the part of a reasonable man to decide on going through college now.
I suppose you are expecting a letter from me but I don't  knows as I shall be able two write you much I am writing and and cannot have any thoughts to myself because of talking it seems more than ever to me that we are located in the corner of creation here all seems to be life and damnation they are the mind for all ((unclear)) up the engines, is this very week surveying the rout for a railroad through this town.  The rout they are looking at how is part of uncle Jo, across the Rabbit farm and (Bimball Whitney?? sp) & Uncle Leonard, but these could be a great while about where it shall go Greenfield folk, say it shall go through that town  or not at all.  I am now at  My 'Gabes ((unclear))' in Ball backs, the school on the brok George Greensbro' (grandson) is a small merchant has a store in the middle of the  town.
Dwight Mayor, teaches ((unclear)) but a many of the young ones are ((unclear)) or the next teachers today or something hardly enough to keep the old ((unlear)) good.

I want to leave school.  All the folks in Mayes I expect would have been here away from all our 'kins folks and acquaintance,' for so long, as to be almost forgotten if not forgetting.
Anything you write will please.  I have got a new coat made, A 'tailored' so called, can wear over another coat generally not.  Pay Dockam $7,50 for making & trimming in the Spring.   I have borrowed ((unclear))  It is ridiculous for me to be so poor.  Too bad for a person of my abilities!  reputation! & Intansic worth!  To teach school for $16 dolls per month.  Especially as a tremendous hard scholar this
Completed

Foxcroft March 3rd 1844, Sunday

Dearest Mother
My roommate's beau came this morning and staid so long that I could not get ready in season to go to meeting;  so I will sped a part of the forenoon in writing to you, although I do not in all cases approve of writing letters Sunday.  Joseph cam up with me last Monday, went to Dexter Tuesday to try to find a chance to work, but did not (unclear)
to go to school.  Isaac & I board together at the Butlers;-not more than three or four roads from the Academy.  We hardly vis. Miss Kint from ((unclear))  Isaac & myself have a comfortable, pretty little parlour (with an airtight stove, rocking settee) and two bedrooms leading from it.  My room has a fire in it.  The price of board is 8/ with washing alone, or 7/6 and do my own washing.  I think I shall do my own & Isaac's too.  Miss ((unclear)) is very amiable, pleasant, handsome, agreeable, pretty too.  I like it a great deal better being in a room by ourselves, (we girls) but we have to go down below to write, which is grievous.  I study Algebra (and if you will believe it, get along nicely therin too; - I  was behind most of the class when I came, but am now ahead all the girls)  ((unclear)) mentor Philosophy, Arithmetic & Grammar.  Oh dear, how I do have to "manipulate" on the board in Algebra & Arithmetic.  Isaac has the Algebra, Mr Park Arithmetic & Miss C, Upham.  If it is a possible thing I shall get excused from going to the board, ((unclear)) be abominable sill that it takes my strength "entirely away"
Completed

it makes me as weak as a sail.  It is foolish I know, but so ill and I cannot help it.
Sunday March 10th - Again I stay at home from meeting, partly on account of a cold, and partly because the walking is very bad.  When I came from home I left cooked a turkey doughnuts, two whole hog shoulders, thirteen loaves of bread and two mince pies!  Didn't I do pretty well?  I find since I came here, that I need some kind of a handsome dress:  having nothing of the kind except my black one, and that I have had four years, and it is entirely out of fashion, besides being ((unclear)) throughout so that it is uncomfortably warm in moderate weather.  My silk one is so small I cannot wear it with flannels at all.  But I don't know if there is any help for it, except to "grin and bear it."  Isaac needs a hat very much, but has not got his money yet for teaching school.  Small means!  "Great minds & small means ruin."  Not that I would insinuation that we have great minds accompanying our small means.  By no means.  I never heard Isaac declaim really in my life till last Wednesday, and he really did much better than I expected.  I laugh at him some for pursuing a College course so far before he has concluded whether to go or not.  If he is not going he had better do something else.  We may not write again before you come home & about getting anything if there is any way to get them - you know what we need I suppose.  The boys need some linen for bosoms & dickeys Isaac especially, much; and I shall have to have something in the shape of clothes very soon.  But you know best.  Aff daughter Lucy.

I don't want nothing as I see but what I can get on do without.  Isaac & Lucy have left not me much room to write I not only do but also I have got not much to write.  The school out on Stanckfield ridge, in which Isaac kept the village school long time ago was consumed by fire last Thursday night.  Daniel Barker for Exeter was keeping the school.  Gilman is at work on the house yet.  I guess expect him 2 weeks longer now.  I guess I feel sleepy & Eliab had it better a gone to Massachussetts .  I don't know what else to write.  Joseph.
Completed

Foxcroft March 10th 184?

Dear Mother
We are all very pleasantly situated here, pleasant rooms.  Can step out of the back door into the Academy yard.
I am on about the same foundation as last autumn; am occupied in the regular excitations just 2 hours out of The Six, at present.
Have a very good class in Algebra, 2 in Grammar & one in Arithmetic besides a private class or so, out of school hours.
And then we are so handy here that we have an abundance of callers, of all kinds, many
come in for assistance in all branches.  I am studying "Menophon" and "Livy", on the regular college course.  I can fit, I suppose
to enter a year in advance this fall, if I try.  I have not concluded!
I am also dipping into the more extended college course of Mathematics.
I am getting along finely, can do up the regular college lessons throughout in a 
few hours per diem.  School commenced with 52 students, &
at present, constantly increasing.  Shall not have more than 100 in all_
pretty good for a Spring term.  Joseph is here now, has been ?
where to get something to do - mind is on every bit studying.
Lucy's health is not very good, perhaps not so good as it was last spring, takes cold easy.
She has been shut up in the house so all winter been out but one or twice till she came here.  No horse, at home, know.
I think her health will improve here, if she is careful, does not have to go but a step or so in bad weather & walking.
I do not believe Eliab has got along so well in study this winter as Lucy has, at home alone, I at work all the time.
She went through Smith thoroughly at home, & is getting along finely in Algebra.
will be one of the best in my class.  We rec'd a letter from Eliab via John Cutler last week or so.  When are you coming home;
I have very little faith in Eliab's going to learn a trade in Boston;
Completed

Foxcroft June 21 1844

Dear
I do not know as I have much of any thing to write just now, certainly not of importance.  I like to write letters home as well as think of home, even if I do not very often hear from these.  Things get along about as usual, and I have just got fairly settled down to my studies again, after my weeks absence, some called it running away
here.  Four new scholars entered the school while I was gone,  Anna Hutchins of Industry, who was here last fall; and there young men from Charleston, who
left here for some reason suddenly, right in the middle of the term.  They were, I should think their three best scholars there, nearly fitted for College, I think of going to Brunswick this fall.  I guess they are really first rate fellows & good scholars.  Isaac W. Case, Dr Case's son of Havant, James K. Bartlett of Harmony and ((unclear)) who was in Milo a year ago.  B.B Sinart, I believe.  If I go to Brunswich they will be my companions these three years, probably.
The school now numbers 42 in all!  Mr. Task did not know but he would have to set me to work again, he said, but I guess he will get along as some are leaving occasionally.
Nancy Carpenter has left. Fratton & Evens, Philbrick was gone last week, Delegate to the great Whig((unclear))
Completed

I found a letter from Joseph in the P.Q when I came up here, if Lucy had waited she might have seen it.
I suppose likely you have heard from him ere this, he wrote that he had written sent or was about to send home.
He says he is not at work in a lath mill for 10,00 ((unclear)) never saw a lath mill.  Saw window blinds 7 ((unclear)) and has $13,00 per month.  He was there week before he obtained permanent  employment in which he earned enough to pay his board & one cent more.
Joseph wrote that there was some probability that in a fortnight, which would be near this time, he should be at work on the fish river road, for the state.  That I suppose is a way up to ((unclear))  100 or 200 miles.
Wrote nothing of the Fish River condition or prospect except $15,00.
Our ((unclear)) is not living yet, afraid it will not before the 'fourth',  There is to be a great Democratic Celebration at Dover.
Whig                     do 
at Levant &            Liberty
up to "Parkman.  Mr Parker I suppose delivers an adds.  I don't know yet whether I shall stay here or go home, or run off somewhere.
Court week, some important cases.  Bol. Paul 8 May ((unclear)) at last decided in favour of Paul.  Unexpected decision.
How would it work for me to go to work for Captain Holmes or some of the big farms, here in laying, for some money.  Guess I might.  James Holmes told me they wanted to hire.  I expect I have got along so I might leave my studies some.  Might work here for money spell, before Charles begins
Completed

Society meeting, this A.M.  Mr Parker went down to south Dover, funeral of Mr. Joseph Foster, a member of this Church.  P.M Mr. Parker text.  Lion is a Desolation.
The present, declaration of religion, it's causes;  finally bought in slavery, or connection of the American Church with it, as one cause;  and spoke the rest of the afternoon
upon it, or at least much longer than usual, and very good too pretty severe too, but I guess offended no one;  people here different from a few years ago.  
Mr. Parker has had a great influence  here, very great in that respect.  He is a very different man from Mr. Wells.
Fourth of July  Bell ringing & powder smoking morning.  As I swam an hour or so yesterday, worked considerable, and was employed late in the evening, I took a fine nap at the whole gun fire & bell ringing this morning.
Alotof our best uns have gone down to Levant this morning, my roommate Chandler, Philbrick, the Charleston fellows, first rate chaps they are, bc  They had a play round of their own 'Foxcroft Academy' 'Class of Rotection'.  The others got an best motto, ((unclear)) and no ((unclear)) I would not go under the 'clay'.
Gout our ((unclear)) up yesterday.  P.M I worked to get it up, considerable job, outside.  They call it ((unclear)) bell in the place.  pleasant tone.
I have received another long letter from Clark, this week
I would to Joseph again but he left me in uncertain, whether to direct to Old town or fish River.  If he wrote to you let me know.
Mr Task', 'Fourth' excites some speculation.  (He went up to Capt. Holmes, where he is a frequent nightly visitor, one Wed eve.  & was not seen in these parts again till Thurs eve, or Fri. morn.    I staid here part of the day, I had a fine ride up to Guilford & about with Clement who was going up & offered me a ride with him.
They had quite a parade here, but I did not care for it, or for H. Hamlings' speeches.  Clay Celebration at Levant.  J. W. Case, who went down from here, read the Declaration Paine Orator.  Mr. Parker delivered an address up to Parkman.
I intend to have sent this letter by (Dr Kimball but he went too soon.
Completed

j                                                                                                                                                                       Brunswick Sept 6th 1844
Dear Mother and Brothers & Sisters;
I am here quietly sealed in my room sabbath day after meeting, and, as I have not before, perhaps it will be no harm to write a letter home.  Today.
I suppose you are all wishing to hear, all how I got here,
how I like, & how I get along.  To begin at the beginning Eliab can  tell how we got to Bangor, & I should like 
to hear from him how he got back.  I don't know as it was right for him to go home so into the sabbath.  What
time did he arrive?  (How does Josephs coat suit.)  You know he can send it back.
I hope Eliab did not get it injured in the rain.  The fact is, I know nothing what he wanted.
He did not even tell me how much he wished to give for one, which would have been a guide you know?
The one I bought was precisely of the new fashion; perhaps you will not like it.  I had only the night to pick it out in, but I guess it is a pretty coat and
cheap.  It was a perfect fit for me.  Mr. Norcross sun. of the Washington House had the male to it, just alike for $12,00
I got it, 25 cheaper for the button lost.
I went to Mr. Pomroys to tea Sunday.  AM gave me $5,00.  I heard Mr. Gough, (from Goff) Sab Eve.  The best temperance between, he has had great effect in Bangor.
The young men need his influence.  It rained much Sab eve, & the wind blew all day hard.  So the steamboat passage was very rough & I was a good deal seasick:  I 
omitted to lay in provisions Sat, and had to get breakfast on board or I should have perished almost.  The aggravations of
seasickness, are increased tenfold by an empty stomach.
The only cure is eating I suffered much for dinner
Completed

Mr Gough was on board & gave us a speech down the bay.
He lectured here Wed.Eve.  We arrived at Portland at dark, two hours late for the extreme sea roughness.
Had to pay, 163 for carrying my trunks to a tavern, & 2,5 'for my lodging alone.  Supper & breakfast both, 12half.  Got to Brunswick in
the stage for $1,00, which was better than to walk, as I probably could not get the trunks carried for 50
It is perhaps a bad thing for Clark that I did not come the week before as I intended.  He concluded I should not come, and cared he could not get another room mate
which would double his bills of rent, fuel, lights.
The day before I came, when he had about given up seeing me;  book, one of last spring term associates, came & wanted to go in with him (Clark is popular) and would buy some nicer furniture.  Under the circumstances, I thought not best to interrupt them though they both offered to.  Cook is rather a Rowdy acquired considerable reputation in the "bagger war??" last spring by "knocking down" a "bagger" in the street, & day time for which however he was 'suspended' a while.
I do not think his influence beneficial upon Clark, who is one of those characters who take their stamp from the company they keep in a great degree.
I had however several other chances offered me.  Among the rest, a certain
Senior, James Newton by name wanted I should come in with him for this term, as his chum is absent.
It would save him half of fuel & lights.  It was a pretty good as his room is well furnished; but it would be going out of my class, which is unpleasant, & I must find a new room mate.
Set up for myself in the spring, which would be more difficult.  His object was said to be to make
Completed

me a ((unclear)), as he is a member of that society.  I have been the past week with a Mr. Baker Wm. W a sophomore, just come from Waterville, Belfast fellow.
He a good clever fellow, a beneficiary, stout, slow, but perhaps strong, might make a good chum, without being a very popular student.
I have bought me a cap, same material as Josephs', but large, big top, & fixed off, quite a cap, for $1,00.
Bought at Griffin, the College monopolist.  ((unclear)) $1,10, ((unclear)) grammar, 70, Sen. Am,55, Hom 1,15.  Total of 43,50 on term bill.  Regardless Geometry I bought second hand for $50, price 1.25.  I ought to have brought Boyer with me.  New one costs $2,25, borrowed ((unclear)) for this term.  Our duties are, Bell about ((unclear)) Prayers in the little old crowded chapel.  Recitation, ((unclear)) week, sic. Ann spoken & Homer Greet Latin is very easy, Green will be when get underweigh, next, Breakfast.
At 9, study hours, everyone required to be in rooms. 11 Rec, in Geometry, very easy so far.  Dinner 2, study hours, 4 French, on which Prof. Goodwin drills us till prayer bell, double time, about.  This is the hardest study to me.  Drives hardest.  Probly because I lost 3 or 4 lessons, which it is very difficult to gain, that is the instructions of Prof. G at recitations.  Pronouncing & cogitating verbs I think hard.  (grows easier very fast)
On the  whole I am getting on finely & expect to.
I am very much obliged to Ann for her loan, under the circumstances might have been short without it.
I  hope you will all take pains & write.
I.J Metcalfe.
Completed

Bangor Dec, 14th, 1844
I sent up a bundle by Mr Dudley, yesterday, with a little scrawl in pencil mark which perhaps you can read;
but as I suppose you will like to know more particularly of my situation and prospects, I think I will write a letter.
I expected Mr. D. would go Thursday instead of Friday, or I should have sent by Mr. Cutts;  I fear you will not get the 
bundle in season to send by Cutts next week.
I walked down to Mr. Dudleys Friday night after Eliab left me;  and Sat went into the city, in the morning.
I was round in the rain all day, but could not get my bunk; Garnsey was gone & by some mismanagement had taken the keys with him.
I wrote a letter to him; and by sending down the next week finally got it, Wednesday.
I staid at Mr. Harlows' till sabbath eve.
By the way they have meetings, here every sabbath & eve.
Some of the students preaching usually, & I suppose I shall be obliged to remain here.  Neither the folks or their preachers
would like it if I did not.
I have got a very pleasant school, about 4 scholars, and considerably forward, most all girls too.
Have a good class of five in Algebra, and good classes in all the common studies, especially in Colburns' Arithmetic
which you know is much thought of here.  The scholars all seem really well disposed, and very bright & intelligent.
If one must teach they could hardly get into a better place.
Completed

for a common school, though the 'little ones' are still a trial and there is opportunity sufficient to exercise patience.
The Committee have not yet visited my school.
I expect to 'have' a writing school in operation pretty soon but it will be a small one, and the Compensation small.
I have been up Capt. Mowers one evening.  Mrs. Mowers says that "Charles, Riches too particular ever to get married!"
Mr. Mower is a fine man I think, a liberty man, & an awful talker.
He has fine family of children.  Six of them attend my school and form a very good part of it, in wits as well as numbers.
Horace Mower has had the reputation of being a very bad fellow, but I am very far from anticipating any trouble from him.
I board in a very pleasant family, Mr. Dudleys, about a third of a mile from the school - house.  I shall have to pay 9/ for board perhaps.
10/6 without washing.  10/6 is the usual price here.  The milliner all pay it, I hardly see why it is so high.
The Brownville teams pass here every day, going to the Ironworks, and into the woods; the West branch teams go through Brownville.
I don't often have a chance to see them, but one at Milo Mills, might send 12 dozen times per day.
If you send - Mr Dudleys, Ed House, half mile above (Bucknam's?)
I am really anxious to hear from home, How does Almeda get along, and does she feel reconciled?
How does Joseph get along with his school - pleasantly?  Let him write to me about it, & everything else.
do him good.  How does Charles get along with the house?  What became of the old bridge?  Will all those oxen & horses eat him out of house & home, this winter?
What is Eliab doing?  Tell him to (improve his precious time.) not that
Completed

tern after me when I am at home there, (only visiting you know?) Get up in the morning.  He don't begin to know yet how much he don't know;  and how much he ought to be learning.  Learn to write.  Write to me.  Do him good.
How is Sister Lucy?  What is she did 'den' on?  I hope she has not forgot how to write; if she has, I shall not have ever to go back to Brunswick.
I wish Ann would write.  And especially my Mother.  She ought not to have too much to do to write to her children, when away.
When is Charles coming to Bangor?  If he can or anybody can, get any money, I wish they would pay Caleb Prentis, Foxcroft, Five dollars, on my account.
To be paid this month.  I don't want to wear my credit,  
I don't know but I must send  up my old coat to be mended.  I thought at first I could not do without it long enough, but it is so bad it can't be worn.
I hate to wear my best one all out;  there is no wear in it.
I wish I had a nightcap made of network, would such a thing be possible?  A silk one would be too warm but my hair troubles me.
Can't Eliab get a school over Pleasant River?  Chadburn thought he could.  Try if not too late.
Wed. eve.  Mr Sherbourne of Milo is here tonight, & I can send this up by him.  He tells me Eliab is keeping school over to his place.  I am glad of it;
guess he will do well.  It is a very small pleasant school, if Bill Martin don't go.  If he will learn those Newcomb girls anything more he ought to have a
pension. I will consider is reputation established as a teacher.
Let him take all pains . Pity he can't write.  Write me all about it.
Completed

Topsham, Jan 17th 1845


Dear Mother
I received your last welcome letter last week, several days since; and was as usual very much gratified with it.  The news too was exactly what I wanted to hear, and
not as you suggested, what I had heard before from any of the Bangor "brethren."
It is now some little time since I have heard from Bangor at all, and when they do write, they write very little news most of them.
Joseph is a very good prompt correspondent, and his letters are always really valuable ones, but they are always filled with all sorts of
Philosophy, scientific & metaphysic speculation and disquisition, interspersed with his peculiar dryness of satire, but usually very studiously
refraining from all fact & news.
Eliab hardly writes at all.  I really wish he would, I want much to be better acquainted with him.
Lucy has written to me once since she has been in Bangor.  Anne wrote me @ beautiful letter as , and indeed containing @ New Year's gift.
Completed

You thought my journey must have been very fatiguing.
I do not know but it was:  I was very sleepy for a couple of days, but I think have felt better for it ever since.
About a fortnight ago we had quite a little fire here one night.  I worked pretty hard at it for a couple of hours;  got pretty wet thoroughly; but never took cold, and it 
really did me good;  have felt better ever since.
I am very glad you like "Proverbial Philosophy" so well.  I knew you would.  It is a book too that, like the Book of books, you will continue to like better and better,
the more you read it.  No one need be afraid of 'wearing it out.'
I should think you must miss Lucy much at Milo:  but if you can get along without her.  I am much rejoiced that she can be at Bangor.
Quite an idea that of the rum seller partly at Bangor threatening Eliab!
Let him go ahead.  I guess he need not be so much alarmed on that score; or rather perhaps you for him.  But let him be careful and not let him
stoop himself to any unworthy, to any 'low' means, anything under the true gentleman.
The end does not justify the means, in manners as in morals.
You say James delights in lecturing Jane "as I did Joseph"!  Did I even though?  Didn't he hector me more?
How far have the young ones got in their studies?  Does Jenny learn
Completed

quick - make a good scholar?  you know she is a great favourite of mine.  I should really like to see both of the little humanities.
What is the reason that hay is so very low?
Just when he happens to have some to sell.  My five months of school will be out in two weeks longer The College Spring term commences in four weeks.
I may teach right on those two weeks and may not.
If I do not, it would be extremely pleasant for me to take a trip down East, about as far as Bangor & Milo, in all respects except the $10 or $12 dollars of expenses.
However I suppose I shall need the time enough to make up Mid Fall term studies, write themes.  Some of my class who have been teaching, have given up their schools already, and some to studying, to prepare for the final contest.  However, I have given up all idea of any struggle for the rank.
Circumstances prevented it entirely in my case.  So I do not care so much.
Jan 18th  I received today letters from Bangor, Joseph & Lucy.
Josephs' was as usual.  The nearest approach to any news there was in it, was
the following answer to my question as to a protest by a Boston Bank of a bill on Folsom & Metcalf, the back of which was wrapper
to his previous letter.  "I wood meat thy question with another, what business is that of yours!" 
Lucy wrote but little, complained of being time wholly occupied.  Not a word from Eliab or of Eliab on the whole!
Completed

The only apology I have for awaiting so soon after receiving yours is that I always get so tired of waiting for letters from you, so long as I am obligated to usually.
I.J Metcalf, Foxham
